title: Mutant fish deformed by Deepwater Horizon oil spill shine light on how air pollution affects humans
text:
CRUDE HEALTH Mutant fish deformed by Deepwater Horizon oil spill shine light on how air pollution affects humans 
Terrifying findings prove that humans are just at risk of killer heart problems from the air as fish polluted with crude oil by MARGI MURPHY Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments MUTANT fish that have suffered heart problems in the wake of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill have shone a light on how air pollution affects humans. 
Scientists claim that the slew of marine life deformities caused by crude oil pollution in the Gulf of Mexico reveal just how pollution in the air we breathe is affecting our health. US COAST GUARD / EPA FILE 4 FTSE has had to pay out billions in compensation, fines and clean-up costs since the disaster in 2010 
The Deepwater Horizon disaster of April 20 , 2010, killed 11 workers and created the worst environmental disaster ever in the US. 
It released a cocktail of nasty toxic chemicals, or polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), into marine life habitats. 
But the infamous event could now help shed a light on the effect widespread pollution is having on humanity, according to a chilling new study by Manchester and Stanford scientists. Deepwater Horizon Film Trailer starring Mark Wahlberg, Kurt Russell, Dylan O'Brien & Kate Hudson AP:Associated Press It killed 11 workers and created the worst environmental disaster ever seen in the US David Lee The film Deepwater Horizon, starring Mark Wahlberg and Kate Hudson, tells the story of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill – a disaster which devastated the oil rig, risking the lives of those who worked there Related stories FUMING MAD Owners of pollution heavy old bangers will be fined £10 'toxicity charge' for driving in London UK TOLD TO CLEAN UP Britain given final warning on air pollution by European Commission TOXIC AIR WARNING Britain sent ‘final warning’ on air pollution for repeated breaches of smog limits in 16 areas JAMIE EAST AT THE MOVIES Disaster flick Deepwater Horizon is an explosive, against-all-odds blockbuster oils well that ends well BP finally on the up after spending billions to cover 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill disaster SOMETHING FISHY Eating fish and seafood riddled with mercury 'raises risk of Stephen Hawking's motor neurone disease' 'I WOULD SHOWER FOUR TIMES A DAY' Woman, 36, who stinks of rotten FISH is forced to work night shifts after colleagues complain 
BP's oil was found to cause heart problems and deformations in developing fish in the surrounding waters in the following years. 
One of these chemicals, called phenanthrene, is particularly adept at destroying heart muscle cells, scientists found. 
And now they believe that phenanthrene - which can be found across the entirety of the Earth's water and air - has far reaching implications for human health, too. 
A paper published by Nature stated: "Phenanthrene is a ubiquitous pollutant in water and air, and the cellular targets for this compound are highly conserved across vertebrates. 
"Our findings therefore suggest that phenanthrene may be a major worldwide cause of vertebrate cardiac dysfunction." 4 The Deepwater Horizon oil spill has cost BP an estimated £47 billion 
They found that the chemicals were linked to "life-threatening" irregular heart rhythms and consequently, we suggest that atmospheric phenanthrene should be a concern for human cardiology, particularly due to its high abundance in urban air and its rapid absorption into the bloodstream after inhalation". 
The scientists warned that regulation of the chemical would be necessary to ensure animal and human safety. 
They wrote: "We have identified a cardio-toxicant compound prominent in crude oil, and shown how it alters cardiac force and cardiac rhythm in pelagic fish. 
"This provides a new framework for evaluating the effects of PAHs on cardiac function that we believe can be extended across a wide range of vertebrates, including humans. 
"Reducing future releases of this pro-arrhythmic chemical should substantively benefit human and ecological health."
